input: Anne is round. Anne is young. Bob is round. Bob is smart. Dave is blue. Dave is kind. Dave is round. Dave is smart. Dave is white. Erin is smart. If someone is round and blue then they are white. Kind people are blue. All round people are kind. White, round people are young. All round, kind people are smart. If Bob is young and Bob is blue then Bob is furry. Furry people are young. Question: Bob is not furry.?
output:
universe u

constant obj : Type u

constant Anne : obj
constant Bob : obj
constant Dave : obj
constant Erin : obj

constant Round : obj → Prop
constant Young : obj → Prop
constant Smart : obj → Prop
constant Blue : obj → Prop
constant Kind : obj → Prop
constant White : obj → Prop
constant Furry : obj → Prop

axiom T1 : Round Anne
axiom T2 : Young Anne
axiom T3 : Round Bob
axiom T4 : Smart Bob
axiom T5 : Blue Dave
axiom T6 : Kind Dave
axiom T7 : Round Dave
axiom T8 : Smart Dave
axiom T9 : White Dave
axiom T10 : Smart Erin

axiom R1 : ∀ x : obj, Round x ∧ Blue x → White x
axiom R2 : ∀ x : obj, Kind x → Blue x
axiom R3 : ∀ x : obj, Round x → Kind x
axiom R4 : ∀ x : obj, White x ∧ Round x → Young x
axiom R5 : ∀ x : obj, Round x ∧ Kind x → Smart x
axiom R6 : ∀ x : obj, Young Bob ∧ Blue Bob → Furry Bob
axiom R7 : ∀ x : obj, Furry x → Young x

theorem bob_is_not_furry : ¬ Furry Bob :=
begin
  sorry
end

-- Looks like it cannot be proven in Lean.
-- So let's try to prove the negation of the theorem, which is Bob is furry

theorem bob_is_furry : Furry Bob :=
begin
  apply R6,
  split,
  apply R4,
  split,
  apply R1,
  split,
  exact T3,
  apply R2,
  apply R3,
  exact T3,
  exact T3,
end

-- It can be proven in Lean. So
-- The answer is False
